text: Racing Post says "Likely improver now upped in trip for his handicap debut" - why should it perform better at the longer distance? Is it the case that trainers are in the habit of deliberately running horses at the wrong distance up until their first handicap race?

elements.text: Racing Post says "Likely improver now upped in trip for his handicap debut" - why should it perform better at the longer distance? Is it the case that trainers are in the habit of deliberately running horses at the wrong distance up until their first handicap race?

text: First time handicapping, longer trip, mark Prescott
Happens all the time
How do we know that 7f wasn't already the horse's optimal distance?

elements.text: How do we know that 7f wasn't already the horse's optimal distance?

text: Sorry we seem to be zig zagging between this sub thread and the main <#C4H05KKMY|random> - probably my fault!

elements.text: Sorry we seem to be zig zagging between this sub thread and the main

text: Well we dont _know_ that. I haven't looked at this particular race but taking into account the horses profile + breeding + trainer etc the prevailing sentiment is clearly that 7f was not the optimal distance and/or the goal was to always go handicapping and the first three runs were used to get a winnable handicap mark and have limited utility on assessing the horses true ability.
Of course that might not be the case, if you believe the opposite to be true then I'd get laying it!

I dare say you're right... I jam just hoping to automate the process of detecting this scenario... for example how about IF first handicap race AND distance very different to previous races THEN => expect improvement.

elements.text: I dare say you're right... I jam just hoping to automate the process of detecting this scenario... for example how about IF first handicap race AND distance very different to previous races THEN => expect improvement.

text: is that the gist of it?

elements.text: is that the gist of it?

text: Yeah it's a tricky one really. I use fundamental models and my general assessment is that the chances of a horse improving significantly over a new distance or first time in handicaps etc is usually overestimated in the market in comparison to its previous form. But there are definitely exceptions
That's very useful - thank you.

I'm not actually much of a betcode user so forgive my ignorance...

I want to extract some data from the free (one minute interval) betfair historical data and write it out as csv so I can process it with my C code. The data I want is something like a snapshot of everything contained in the image below (for all races in a date range) at a certain time of day  or perhaps a certain number of minutes before the start of a race. So my question is, what would be the least painful way to do this? Does betcode (or flumine?) have this kind of functionality built in already? Or has someone made some other kind of utility to do this?
